questions.text: A 20-year-old presented with a non-progressive hypopigmented skin lesion that has been present since birth. It shows white accentuation under Wood's lamp examination, and diascopy is inconclusive. What is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
Explanation:

The clinical scenario here points to the diagnosis of nevus depigmentosus.

Definition:

  • Nevus depigmentosus is a rare, congenital, stable hypomelanosis.

Clinical Presentation:

  • Lesions appear as off-white macules with irregular, serrated, feathered, or geographic margins.
  • Commonly located on the trunk, lower abdomen, and proximal extremities.
  • It can appear in dermatomal or quasi-dermatomal distribution.
  • Facial involvement may lead to social embarrassment.

Course:

  • Stable throughout life; lesions do not change in size or distribution.
  • Primarily limited to the skin, but rare associations with:
    • Neurological abnormalities
    • Limb hypertrophy

Diagnosis - Commonly Used Clinical Criteria:

  • Leukoderma present at birth or with early onset
  • No change in the distribution of the lesion over time
  • Normal texture and sensation in the affected area
  • No hyperpigmented border around the lesion

Treatment:

  • Generally, no effective treatment exists.
  • However, suction blister grafting has shown success in individual cases.

Vitiligo (Option A) is unlikely because it is an acquired, progressive condition characterized by complete melanocyte loss, and it typically does not present at birth.

Nevus anemicus (Option C) is a vascular anomaly where the lesion disappears with diascopy due to vasoconstriction; since diascopy is inconclusive in this case, it is not consistent with nevus anemicus.

Indeterminate leprosy (Option D) is ruled out because it is acquired, may be progressive, and often involves sensory loss, none of which is present in this case.

Reference:

https://pmc.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/articles/PMC3657231/#

questions.text: An image shows the characteristic skin findings of phrynoderma, described as plugged keratotic papules. Which of the following should be done next?
questions.solution:
Explanation:

The image described shows plugged keratotic papules, which are characteristic of phrynoderma-a cutaneous manifestation of vitamin A deficiency and potentially other nutritional deficiencies.

  • Phrynoderma is often associated with vitamin A deficiency, which also causes ocular symptoms.
  • Ocular signs may include:
    • Night blindness
    • Conjunctival xerosis
    • Corneal ulcerations
  • These symptoms may be subclinical or underreported, so it is crucial to actively assess ocular involvement.
  • Early detection of ocular involvement helps in prompt management and prevention of vision loss.

Treatment

  • First-line Management:
    • Nutritional correction.
    • Vitamin supplementation.
    • Treatment of underlying causes (e.g., malabsorption, anorexia).
  • Vitamin A Dosing (Oral):
    • Age ≥8 years and adults:
      • 100,000 units/day for 3 days
      • Then 50,000 units/day for 2 weeks
      • Then 10,000 units/day for 2 months
    • Oral administration is preferred over parenteral.

Vitamin D3 status (Option B): Checking vitamin D3 status is not directly relevant in the context of phrynoderma, as vitamin D deficiency is more commonly associated with musculoskeletal symptoms

Deep tendon reflexes (Option C): Assessing deep tendon reflexes evaluates neurological function, which is not typically affected in phrynoderma

Vitamin B12 status (Option D): Measuring vitamin B12 levels may be relevant in cases of general malnutrition, but it is less immediately necessary than assessing for ocular involvement, which is a known and significant complication of vitamin A deficiency.

questions.text: A patient presents with a plaque on the face with central clearing and atrophy, and his chest X-ray demonstrates apical calcification. Which of the following can be used for the diagnosis of the underlying condition?
questions.solution:
Explanation:

A patient presenting with a skin lesion along with apical calcification on chest X-ray raises a strong suspicion for cutaneous tuberculosis, particularly in the setting of prior or latent pulmonary tuberculosis.

  • Cutaneous TB can manifest in several forms, including lupus vulgaris, which is often paucibacillary and challenging to confirm microbiologically.
  • While diagnosis may be suggested by clinical appearance and histopathology, the only definitive diagnostic methods for cutaneous TB are:
    • Tissue culture
    • Cytological smear
    • Detection of Mycobacterium tuberculosis DNA via PCR
  • Among these, PCR (Polymerase Chain Reaction) is especially valuable because it enables the rapid and specific detection of tuberculosis DNA, even in paucibacillary lesions such as lupus vulgaris, where conventional methods may fail.
  • PCR techniques utilize targets such as IS6110, MPB-64, or 16S rRNA genes, and have demonstrated good sensitivity and specificity in cutaneous TB, with overall sensitivities ranging from 73% to 100% in multibacillary cases.

Mantoux test (Option B) is a supportive test but not diagnostic, as it only indicates prior exposure or immune response to TB antigens and may be positive in latent TB, BCG vaccination, or other mycobacterial infections.

Slit skin smear test (Option C) is used to diagnose leprosy, not tuberculosis.

Probe test (Option D) is a clinical bedside test used to check for sinus tract depth or bone involvement, particularly in scrofuloderma, but it is not a diagnostic tool for identifying the pathogen.
